metadata.title: Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Patellofemoral joint/knee cap, including articular cartilage and soft tissue attachments to patella
description: Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS) is one of the most common knee disorders affecting physically active adolescents and adults(3)
PFPS is a major cause of anterior knee pain that limits ADLs and sports participation, especially in running and jumping(10)
Rehabilitation protocols for patients with PFPS should address underlying functional deficits at the hip and core as well as at the knee(11,12)

ICD-10 codes.M22.9: disorder of patella, unspecified (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Depends on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement for PFPS has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Anterior knee pain(30,31) –“Circle sign” – patient circles kneecap with fingers
Knee stiffness associated with(30,31) –prolonged knee flexion in sitting (moviegoer’s sign) –driving or watching a movie
Activity-related  knee pain(30,31) –Running –Squatting –Stair-climbing,  especially on descent –Kneeling –Cycling –Swimming breaststroke (pain related to whip kick)
Retropatellar tenderness on manual compression of kneecap(30)
Other potential knee signs and symptoms(30) –Crepitation or “grating” sensation –Giving-way
Deficits or imbalances in hip muscle strength(11) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Lack of specific patient and referring physician consent to perform the knee examination
Associated knee joint pathology that may contribute to altered knee/patella posture and gait mechanics, such as potential meniscal or ligament injury
Patient unable to comprehend procedure because of cognitive impairment
Unresolved knee injury, inflammation, or infection
Night pain, fever, pallor, and anorexia may be signs of malignancy (e.g., osteosarcoma)
Older adults with physical frailty and/or severe osteoporosis require extra precaution to minimize injury and pain

causes: Compressive and shearing forces to undersurface of patella(5,9,30)

Lateral maltracking or displacement of the patella.(5,9,22,29,30)Contributing factors include–tight lateral retinacular attachments to the patella–tight/inflexible sartorius, rectus femoris, biceps femoris, vastus lateralis, or iliotibial band–weak medial tracking forces (vastus medialis muscle) compared to lateral forces (vastus lateralis muscle, iliotibial band)–weak hip abductors and external rotators–weak hip extensors
Patellofemoral instability with recurrent lateral subluxation(5,9)
pathogenesis: Anterior knee pain in patients with PFPS is associated with the patellofemoral joint surface(30,31)–Softening, thinning, and fibrillation of retropatellar articular cartilage on MRI or arthroscopy–Pathological changes in cartilage likely activate nociceptors and produce crepitation–“Kissing lesions” occur on femoral condyle opposite affected areas of patella
Impairments affecting the patellofemoral joint include unbalanced quadriceps muscle pulling on the patella, malalignmentof the joint surfaces, and excessive knee valgus or Q-angle(30)
risk factors: Lower extremity malalignment in standing(5)–Foot hyperpronation–Genu valgum–Excessive external tibial torsion–Excessive Q-angle  (greater than 15°). However, authors of a cohort study (N = 22 women with PFPS) in Brazil found norelationships between Q-angle  and pain intensity, functional capacity, or hip abductor peak torque(12)–Excessive hip internal rotation or abduction(13)–Patella alta
Prolonged rearfoot eversion during walking or running(9)
High knee abduction load (moment) during landing in teenage female volleyball, soccer, and basketball players(14)
Altered hip kinematics and weakness in the frontal and transverse planes (i.e., hip drop or increased femoral internalrotation) during functional tasks(9)
Tight lateral retinacular attachments to the patella, as well as decreased flexibility of the hip flexors, hamstrings,quadriceps, or iliotibial band(29,30,32)
Muscle weakness, notably in the vastus medialis obliquus (VMO), hip abductors, and hip external rotators(29,32)

Authors of a cohort EMG study (N = 50) in India found significantly lower VMO/vastus lateralis activation ratios inpatients with PFPS compared to normal controls.(3) The activation ratio averaged 1:1 in normal subjects versus less than1:1 for patients

Type of training(30,31)–Long-distance  running; risk increases with surface terrain and poor shoe cushioning–Hills–Stairs–Breaststrokers (swimmers) – there is increased stress with repetitive whip kicking
History of trauma or degenerative changes to articular cartilage

overall contraindications precautions: In cases of recent knee trauma with visible skin injury and inability to bear weight, rule out fracture and soft tissue injuries and test neurovascular status
Evaluate for safety limitations, such as joint ROM, weight bearing, and illnesses that may affect therapeutic planning
Rule out referred pain from serious back or hip disease, especially in children
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Lack of specific patient and referring physician consent to perform the knee examination
Associated knee joint pathology that may contribute to altered knee/patella posture and gait mechanics, such as potential meniscal or ligament injury
Patient unable to comprehend procedure because of cognitive impairment
Unresolved knee injury, inflammation, or infection
Night pain, fever, pallor, and anorexia may be signs of malignancy (e.g., osteosarcoma)
Older adults with physical frailty and/or severe osteoporosis require extra precaution to minimize injury and pain

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Patellar maltracking is often a contributing factor, especially combined with the repetitive stress of aggravating activities (jumping, running, cycling, climbing, squatting, and kneeling) or training overuse. Considered a condition that may have multiple contributing factors, there is a growing body of evidence that hip dysfunction may also be involved(11,12)

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management for PFPS. Initial nonoperative treatment options include pain management, knee bracing, and activity modification. How has the pain responded to treatment?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the clinician has prescribed, if any; are they being taken and are they effective? Common analgesic medications prescribed for this condition include acetaminophen, NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin, ibuprofen, naproxen), and topical NSAIDs (salicylic acid, diclofenac)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Ask about results of any X-rays  or MRI studies. The two basic views are anterior-posterior
and lateral. The Merchant view is taken at 30° knee flexion, legs relaxed and off end of Xray  table. The Merchant view
can show any mediallateral  direction or tilt of the patella
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Has patient received acupuncture or tried taping/bracing knee or using ice for pain?
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other related conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (note length of time each factor is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Patients often complain of increased pain with running, cycling, or swimming breaststroke. Squatting, stair climbing, or kneeling may also be painful. Knee stiffness may increase with prolonged knee flexion in sitting (e.g., driving, watching a movie) -Following bouts of rigorous activity, pain is typically relieved with rest
history of present illness.body chart: If areas other than anterior knee are involved, use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Patient commonly complains of anterior knee pain
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Patient may report knee crepitation, giving-way,  stiffness, and pain. Locking, catching, clicking, and swelling are unusual
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment. Specifically address if pain is a common symptom and whether it is present now and how much
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document whether there are changes in symptoms throughout the day and night (i.e., a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to knee symptoms, if applicable. Does the patient have strategies (e.g., position or pillow) to avoid knee pain during sleep?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that might exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could indicate need for physician consultation, such as falling because of pain or fever/night pain found in osteosarcoma Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes____ No____ -If Yes, describe________________________ -Is patient communication/education limited by cognitive impairment?

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Are there coexisting problems, such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease, dementia, psychiatric disorders, or movement dysfunction?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs and supplements)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient if there are any symptoms in addition to knee pain (low back, sacroiliac, groin, or hip)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does knee pain occur during participation in certain occupational or recreational activities? Does patient participate in high-risk  activities (running stairs, full squats, lunges, or breaststroke)?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does knee pain interfere with ADLs or use of adaptive equipment?
social and occupational history.living environment: Are there barriers in the home that restrict access, such as stairs; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate need, proper fit, and use of brace, cane, crutches, walker, or wheelchair
relevant tests and measures.balance: Compare time and symptom response for single-leg  stance of affected leg to opposite side. Assess reaction to displacement of center of gravity in standing position
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess peripheral pulses, which should be intact bilaterallyIs the patient able to sit-to-stand  without pain or using the chair armrests? Do the patient’s knees come together when getting out of a chair, and can the patient keep them apart when asked to do so? Does keeping knees apart change the patient’s symptoms in any way? Mobility tests to consider are the timed up-and-go (TUG) test, single-hop  test, step-down  test, and stair descent
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Inspect lower extremity alignment and movement in walking on treadmill. Examine for lateral patellar tracking, femoral anteversion, tibial torsion, and prolonged or excessive rearfoot eversion. Compare sidesAssess passive mobility and dynamic tracking of the patella and tightness of lateral retinaculum in supine and standing positions. If history suggests instability, assess for injury to knee ligaments and menisci. Compare to unaffected knee
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of knee, ankle, and hip musculature; compare to contralateral side. It is common for patients with PFPS to have weakness with hip abduction and external rotation.(29)Assess ability to perform single-leg  squat or a step-down  test without hip internal rotation or adduction
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess alignment of trunk, pelvis, and lower extremities. Assess knee and leg alignment for position of the patella and increased Q-angle. Assess for subtalar pronation if indicated (e.g., use navicular drop test)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active and passive ROM at knee and hip joint. Assess flexibility of iliotibial band, quadriceps, hamstrings, and gastrocnemius. Complete a gross ROM examination of ankle and hip joints. Individuals with PFPS  typically have impaired hip ROM. Talocrural hypomobility limiting ankle joint dorsiflexion may contribute to anterior knee pain(21)Assess Achilles and patellar tendon reflexes, which should be normalEvaluate ability in ADLs affected by patient’s pain and/or weakness
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensation in the affected lower extremity should be intact
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Clarke’s sign test (also known as the patella grind test and the shrug test).(30)Patient lies in supine position with knee extended and is asked to contract quadriceps while examiner applies pressure with web of hand slightly proximal to the upper pole (base) of patella to resist cephalad movement of patella. Compare to contralateral side. Test positive if contraction is inhibited by provocation of retropatellar pain or apprehension of pain. However, the amount of manual pressure applied is problematic for diagnostic accuracy –“J-sign”  test – patient performs active knee extension in standing from 90° flexion, as in single-leg  squat (test positive if patella deviates strongly laterally at terminal extension) –Lateral pull test – patient in supine position with lower extremity extended; instruct patient to contract knee extensors— clinician should observe tracking of patella; significant movement of the patella laterally indicates positive test –Patella glide test – assess mobility in frontal plane by manually translating patella superiorly, inferiorly, medially, and laterally –Patella tilt test – with patient relaxed in supine position and hip joint neutral, assess for tightness of lateral attachments by lifting lateral border (test positive if it cannot be raised to at least horizontal) and for laxity of medial attachments by lifting medial border (test positive if it tilts more than contralateral side) –Ober’s test – for tightness of iliotibial band and tensor fascia lata –Thomas test – for tightness of the quadriceps and hip flexors –Lower Extremity Function Scale (LEFS) –Numeric Pain Rating Scale (NPRS)

contraindications precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Stimulation through or across the chest
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
Over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor or malignancy is present in the area
In the area of a DVT or thrombophlebitis
Over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia
Patients who cannot communicate effectively (i.e., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(1)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: PFPS/anterior knee pain that interferes with physical functioning in ADLs and sports
assessment plan of care.rule out: Degenerative joint disease of the knee, meniscal injury, osteochondritis dissecans, popliteal cyst, prepatellar bursitis, plica syndrome, ligament injury, patellar tendinitis, and Osgood-Schlatter  syndrome
prognosis: Generally good when aggravating activities/risk factors are modified or restricted, although only about one-third  of patients become completely pain free(16)
Identifying and treating symptoms at early onset of symptoms improves prognosis
Patients with coexisting knee conditions have a poorer prognosis
Patients who have experienced symptoms for more than 12 months have a poorer prognosis

Authors of a 2015 meta-analysis  (N = 748 patients with PFPS in 15 studies) found moderate evidence that exercise therapy has a strong pain-reducing  effect and reduces activity limitations and participation restrictions(17)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: For X-ray  if patella fracture or laterally deviated femoral groove is suspected. For MRI if coexisting knee joint pathology is suspected. To orthotist if orthotics or custom bracing is needed. To aquatic therapist for unloading lower extremity during exercise
other considerations: Authors of an RCT (N = 30) in Turkey found that a triple injection of PRP (plasma-rich  protein) compared to a single injection did not result in greater improvement in knee function, isokinetic muscle strength, endurance training, balance, and proprioception in participants undergoing a 6-week  standard exercise program(6)

Authors of a study (N = 40 patients with PFPS) in Greece found that addition of Mulligan’s mobilization-with-movement (MWM) techniques to the knee joint prior to hip and knee exercises (3 times per week for 5 weeks)improved pain (V AS) and function (LEFS) within 1 week(8)
treatment summary: Traditional approaches to rehabilitation for PFPS have focused on local factors at the knee associated with patellar maltracking) or faulty foot mechanics. Evidence consistently supports hip strengthening exercises, specifically addressing the abductor and external rotation muscle groups(29)

Therapeutic exercise may decrease pain in patients with PFPS(2,16,17) –Authors of a 2015 Cochrane review of 31 RCTs and quasi-RCTs  (N = 1,690 participants with PFPS) found low-quality but consistent evidence that exercise therapy is associated with clinically important reduced pain, as well as improved functional ability and enhanced long-term  recovery(2) –Authors of a 2017 RCT in Lebanon concluded that starting with a hip exercise program improved functional abilities, as assessed by the Kujala questionnaire. Starting with knee exercises improved muscle performance, assessed with the single-leg  hop test(24) -30 patients with patellofemoral pain syndrome were randomized into two groups -Group A consisted of 15 patients undergoing 4 weeks of hip strengthening exercises, measuring all variables, and then proceeding with 4 additional weeks of knee exercises -Group B consisted of 15 patients undergoing knee exercises for the first 4 weeks, measuring all variables, and then proceeding with the hip strengthening exercises. All variables were again measured at the end of the 8 weeks for both groups –Authors of a systematic review of four level 1b RCTs compared functional outcomes and pain between patients with PFPS in two exercise interventions. All four studies directly compared knee-  focused exercises (strengthening and stretching) combined with hip strengthening with knee-focused  exercises alone. The statistically significant improvements in pain and function in all four studies supported the hip and knee strengthening exercise program(25)

Foot orthoses –Authors of a 2015 systematic review of 11 RCTs found that foot orthoses had significant effects on pain and function and a slight effect on lower limb kinematics and muscle activation(4) –In Denmark, authors of a 2018 RCT found that foot-targeted  exercises combined with foot orthoses and knee exercises resulted in improved outcomes over knee-focused  exercises alone in individuals with PFPS(27) -40 adults (28 women, 12 men)with PFPS were screened for excessive calcaneal eversion and randomized into a group that performed knee-targeted  exercises only or a group that performed knee exercises plus foot-targeted  exercises and orthoses -Exercises were prescribed 3x per week for 12 weeks -Scores on the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS) pain subscale at 4-month  follow-up  were significantly better in the foot-targeted exercise and orthoses group. At 12 months there was no significant difference between groups –Authors of a RCT conducted in 2015 in Iran concluded that adding risk-factor assessment to an exercise program may enhance treatment effects on function and pain levels at 12-week  follow-up  in patients with PFPS(23) -A total of 53 participants completed the trial: 26 in the intervention group, 27 in the control group -The intervention group had significant improvements in pain with ADLs (V AS 0- to 100-point  scale) and functional outcomes (Kujala patellofemoral score 0- to 100-point  scale))

Patellar bracing –Authors of a 2016 RCT in Germany found that patients with PFPS benefited from a medially directed patellar realignment brace and supervised exercise(26) -156 patients were randomly assigned to 12 weeks of physiotherapy alone or physiotherapy in combination with a brace -Outcomes were measured at baseline, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year -The Kujala score and V AS were improved in the physiotherapy and brace group at 6 and 12 weeks. After 1 year of follow-up  the improvement had diminished

Patellar taping –Authors of a 2015 systematic review and meta-analysis  of 11 studies of participants with PFPS found that Kinesio taping may reduce pain, facilitate muscle activity, and improve motor function. Also, the McConnell taping technique may reduce pain and improve patellar alignment(7) –In contrast, authors of a 2015 systematic review (8 studies, N = 220 participants with anterior knee pain) of the effect of McConnell taping on knee biomechanics found no significant benefit regarding average knee extensor moment, average VMO/vastuslateralis ratio, or average VMO-vastus  lateralis onset timing(18) ›Foot strike in runners

Authors of a biomechanics study (N = 16 healthy female runners) in the United States found that emphasizing a forefoot strike pattern decreased patellofemoral joint stress independent of step length(19)

Authors of a 2017 RCT in the United States investigated the effects of retraining the gait from rearfoot strike to forefoot strike in the management of PFPS in recreational runners(28) –Sixteen participants were randomly assigned to the control (n = 8) or experimental (n = 8) group. All participants performed a treadmill test. The experimental group performed 8 training sessions in which they switched from a rearfoot- to forefoot-strike  pattern; the control group received no interventions –There were no significant differences in heart rate, respiratory exchange ratio, and running economy up to 1 month post-retraining.  Knee pain reported on V AS was significantly reduced in the forefoot-strike  group

Barefoot running may also promote a forefoot-strike  pattern compared to wearing shoes(20) . maintenance or prevention: An early closed kinetic-chain  strengthening treatment program for hip, pelvic stability, knee, and foot may help prevent anterior knee pain from becoming chronic
